holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts on factum of separation, animus deserendi, absence of consent and no reasonable cause accepted; applied Explanation to s.10(1)(a) and desertion test from precedents.

holdings.text: The husband's marriage to Countess Rita did not have any such impact on the mind of the wife so as to cause her to continue to live apart and continue the desertion.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily the fact that he had married Countess Rita on May 17, 1955 would have furnished a just cause to the wife to desist from making any attempt at reconciliation or resuming cohabitation but this is subject to a very important condition, namely, that the second marriage should have had such an impact on the mind of the wife so as to cause her to continue to live apart and continue the desertion. If the conduct of the husband has had no such effect on her mind it cannot be said that the desertion on her part terminated by reason of the conduct of the husband.

holdings.text: Provisions of the Hindu Married Women's Right to Separate Residence and Maintenance Act 1946 and Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act 1956 do not mean that husband's remarriage affords reasonable cause for desertion under s.10(1)(a) HMA.

anchor.surface_text: The consideration that in case the husband remarries, the wife is entitled to separate residence and maintenance under the Hindu Married Womens Right to Separate Residence and Maintenance Act 1946 or any other enactment could not be utilized as a reason for coming to the conclusion that the fact of the remarriage of the husband must necessarily afford a reasonable cause for desertion.

holdings.text: Section 10 of the HMA and s.18 of the HAMA are quite distinct and one cannot be said to control the other; s.18(2) does not amend or abrogate s.10 HMA.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 of the Act and s. 18 of the Maintenance Act are quite distinct and one cannot be said to control the other. Section 18 provides for grant of maintenance to wife alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HMA is codifying with s.4 overriding effect; distinct remedies - judicial separation vs maintenance; no express repeal.

holdings.text: The HMA being a codifying enactment, on matters specifically dealt with therein, provisions of the Act alone apply and courts cannot look to other laws.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily the fact that he had married Countess Rita on May 17, 1955 would have furnished a just cause to the wife to desist from making any attempt at reconciliation or resuming cohabitation but this is subject to a very important condition, namely, that the second marriage should have had such an impact on the mind of the wife so as to cause her to continue to live apart and continue the desertion. If the conduct of the husband has had no such effect on her mind it cannot be said that the desertion on her part terminated by reason of the conduct of the husband.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 of the Act and s. 18 of the Maintenance Act are quite distinct and one cannot be said to control the other. The former provision deals with the matrimonial offences by either spouse which would justify the grant of a decree for judicial separation. Section 18 provides for grant of maintenance to wife alone.

Section 10 of the Act and s. 18 of the Maintenance Act are quite distinct and one cannot be said to control the other. The former provision deals with the matrimonial offences by either spouse which would justify the grant of a decree for judicial separation. Section 18 provides for grant of maintenance to wife alone.

The preamble of the Act describes it as one to amend and codify the law relating to marriage among Hindus. It is well known that when a particular branch of law is codified it is intended and the object essentially is that on any matter specifically dealt with by that law it should be sought for in the codified enactment alone
ive apart from the husband. In Sirigiri Pullaiah v. Srigiri Rushingamma 1  it was held that the effect of the two afforesaid Acts was that a wife was
